entry.title: From idea to app: using AI-powered Project Accelerator to develop SAP Fiori apps
entry.content:
Why use the AI-powered Project Accelerator from SAP Fiori tools?

Imagine you're with colleagues or customers, standing at a whiteboard, sketching the UI of your future SAP Fiori elements app to determine what UI will meet your business requirements.

 

Or maybe you're designing the data model for that app:

 

 

What are the typical next steps to build a working SAP Fiori elements app?

You would normally:

  • Create a data model
  • Prepare the mock data
  • Build an OData service
  • Generate the SAP Fiori app
  • Add the necessary annotations

Now, with the AI-powered Project Accelerator from SAP Fiori tools, you can skip all those steps. Let the AI generate everything for you‚Äîincluding the data model, OData service, sample data, and UI annotations. How much time will that save you in your project? In this post, I‚Äôll explain how to use this powerful new capability, including the steps to set up a trial account and try it for yourself.

Generating a prototype quickly is critical for gathering user feedback

At SAP, we frequently engage with customers in focused co-innovation events. Typically, these involve customers and SAP domain and product experts brainstorming solutions with designers. Then, a couple of dedicated developers invest hours (or even pull all-nighters) to create a prototype for next-day validation and refinement.

These bootcamps are incredibly productive, with every moment of collaboration being invaluable. The desire to expedite review and update cycles by seeing prototypes instantly has always been strong. Now, with the integration of AI technologies into our SAP Fiori tools, this instant prototyping is a reality‚Äîfirst for our internal development teams and now for all SAP customers seeking the same advantages.

In a few minutes, starting with a document, sketch, or other visual representation of your app, you can preview the UI of your list report ‚Äì object page app.

List Report:

Object Page:

The generated project is fully compliant with SAP Fiori tools and can be deployed as a productive application when complete.

 

Ready to try out the AI-powered Project Accelerator?

 

Get started with either a paid SAP Build Code subscription or a free basic trial account.

Setup Steps with SAP Build Code subscription

You‚Äôll need an SAP BTP account with an SAP Build Code subscription. Create a Full-Stack Dev Space containing both the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) and SAP Fiori tools extensions.

Setup Steps with a free basic trial.

Alternatively, use a free basic trial of SAP Build Code.
More details here:
üëâSAP Trial Developer Tools

Note: the free basic trial may have limited quota for AI scenarios.

Click Try Now to generate your trial user ID and password.

Create Your First Project

  1. Log in to your SAP Build Code basic trial account.

  2. Open the Basic Trial ‚Äì SAP Build Code Workbook.

  3. Follow the steps in Unit 2 ‚Äì Create Project to create your Full-Stack Dev Space.

  4. At Step 6, personalize:

    • Project name (e.g., travels)

    • Description (e.g., Fiori Tools AI)

    • Dev space name (e.g., tryFioriToolsAI)

üìåYou do not need to complete any other chapters in the workbook.

Use the Project Accelerator

  1. In SAP Build Code, right-click in the left panel and select SAP Fiori.

  2. Open the Project Accelerator section.

The Project Accelerator is the AI component of SAP Fiori Tools that connects to a large language model (LLM) on SAP BTP. It automatically generates all artifacts for your application.

In the Application Requirements section, provide your business requirements.

Alternatively, you can use /fiori-gen-spec-app command in Joule. It will recognize your request and redirect you to the Project Accelerator:

 

Provide Your Business Requirements

As an input, you can use:

  • Text descriptions (Example 2: Display Customers with Related Contracts)

  • Images (Example: Manage Travel List Report Page). An image can represent a single page UI corresponding to the List Report Page or Object Page floorplan or a data model.

  • Combination of text and images (Example: Manage Travel App). If you want to add multiple images representing different app pages, you should use the combination of text and images, explaining in the text what the images referrer to.

Prepare user requirements as outlined above. For example, download an image of the data model from this blog, then:

  1. Open your workspace folder in SAP Build Code:

    • Go to File > Open Folder...

    • Select /home/user/projects/

  2. Create a folder under "Projects" (e.g., Requirements).

  3. Upload the image:

    • Right-click the folder and select Upload‚Ä¶

 

4. Switch to SAP Fiori from Explorer.

5. In Project Accelerator, click Choose File and select the uploaded image.

Then, click Generate.

 

Preview Your App

In a few minutes, the app will appear in the staging area with two options:

  • Accept Project

  • Preview

Feel free to review the code in the generated artefacts.

You can also select Preview to launch the CAP server and view the app in a new browser tab.

You‚Äôll see an SAP Fiori elements app with:

  • A List Report (filter bar + table of travels)

  • A Travel Object Page

  • A Booking Detail Page (second object page)

 

 

If the generated app meets your needs, press Accept to move it to your dev space.

You can then use SAP Fiori tools to adjust your application UI. For more information on using SAP Fiori tools, see Getting Started with SAP Fiori tools

entry.title: Parallel universes: the dual nature of UX and AI among SAP customers at Sapphire 2025
entry.content:
Sapphire 2025 was interesting and revealing. In the keynotes, theater sessions, and ASUG breakouts, SAP experts and executives talked about the latest innovations around artificial intelligence (AI), data, and user experience (UX). The customer questions and survey responses, however, revealed a parallel universe. Many organizations are on such old systems that they are not able to consume SAP‚Äôs cool new functionality. In this post, I will discuss some of my observations, based on conversations with customers and partners, and share some polling I did in one of my sessions on the intersection between SAP Fiori and AI. I will also include links to several slide decks, recorded demos, and on-demand sessions where you can dive deeper into UX and AI topics.

Customers are starting to use AI, but still behind on SAP Fiori UX adoption

In ERP1612, ‚ÄúEnhancing User Experience with SAP Fiori and AI‚Äù, I asked the audience of around 120 people how they are using AI in their companies. 96 people responded.

 

The 56% percent of the people who are using AI in some way is a big jump from the 37% who responded at ASUG Tech Connect last fall. The main topic in both sessions was SAP Fiori, so the audience profile should be somewhat similar, although the Tech Connect attendees might be more technical as opposed to the business focus at Sapphire.

View the slides from ERP1612.

https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/embed_code/key/1T0gHqRT6X9ddr?hostedIn=slideshare&page=upload

The central theme was SAP Fiori, so it made sense to level set on where people are on their adoption journey. My expectations were high since SAP Fiori has been available since 2013. Since then, our team has spent many hours talking to 1000s of customers and partners about building SAP Fiori apps and how to streamline the process using our tools and technologies such as SAP Fiori elements, SAP Fiori tools, and new AI accelerators.

But, the reality was very different. Only 9 of 109 respondents are using SAP Fiori across their organizations. 43% are still in the planning stage.

 

 

To help customers move to SAP Business Suite, we had many sessions. One that‚Äôs available on demand is ‚ÄúEmbark on a successful transformation journey to SAP Business Suite,‚Äù featuring Maura Hameroff, Priyadarsana Panda, and Soeren Ruder.

Arpan Shah describes how SAP Business Suite drives transformational value through the suite‚Äôs strength and software-as-a-service qualities with integrated processes, data, and AI in the on-demand session ‚ÄúLeverage the benefits of SAP Business Suite in your cloud strategy.‚Äù

There were some nice demos of the latest SAP user experience in ‚ÄúSAP's user experience strategy to achieve better outcomes‚Äù by Arin Bhowmik and Emil Voutta.

Tom Reiss also had some great sessions on SAP Fiori innovations with nice demos, but unfortunately, they were not recorded.

Dr. Tom Reiss before his session.

AI in SAP Cloud ERP wowed the crowd

In Chris Hoffmann‚Äôs session, BAI1362, which I heard several people say was the best talk of the entire Sapphire, he showed several key innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Here are the slides and demos from his presentation:

  • Slides in PDF format
  • Insights card creation with Joule
  • AI-assisted easy filter
  • AI-assisted smart summarization
  • AI-assisted error explanation
  • AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home
  • SAP Fiori elements Project Accelerator

Chris Hoffmann during his talk about adding AI to SAP Fiori apps at both design time and runtime

Several executives from SAP and our customers discussed how AI is transforming business. See their session ‚ÄúHarness the benefits of data and AI in ERP and drive innovation‚Äù on demand.

For a bigger picture view on where these AI innovations fit into the broader SAP Business Suite, watch ‚ÄúTransform your enterprise with the power of SAP Business Suite.‚Äù

SAP Sapphire is a great place for discovery

The new (to SAP) harmonized product operating model focuses on discovery. Interacting with customers to understand their needs plays a big role for product managers and everyone involved in the development process. Sapphire and the after-hours events provide a great venue for conversations with customers about the problems they want to solve.

Since I‚Äôm known for my interest in user experience topics, most of my meetings and questions in my sessions focused on UX and adjacent topics. One of my goals was to gather feedback on what we show and address questions about what people need. While people seemed to like the new AI functionality in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition that Chris and I showed in our respective sessions, the most common question was when it is coming to private cloud (planned) and on-prem (not planned).

There were several sessions on organizational change management, which seemed to be one of the main reasons that people have not migrated off the SAP GUI, even though they like to complain about it. Some of the main takeaways from the OCM panel were:

  • Prioritize people not technology
  • Change management takes a toll on people ‚Äì prep for the after.
  • Don‚Äôt lose sight of the goal and decommission the old technology. Make sure to listen and be agile.
  • The journey will be difficult, acknowledge this and over-communicate.

I really enjoyed Paul Saunders‚Äô entertaining and informative sessions on ‚ÄúLeveraging dark data for enhanced decision-making‚Äù and ‚ÄúAntifragile enterprises: How true resilience comes from embracing change.‚Äù These too were not recorded.

The panel on antifragile enterprises: How true resilience comes from embracing change

Too much content; too little time

Content overload was a common theme I heard from many of the people I spoke with at Sapphire. There were so many sessions crammed into the compressed 2-day format (compared to three days in years past).

BTP remained a hot topic, with many people looking to understand the best way to obtain value.

Discover SAP Business Technology Platform and its value for your business is a good overview on this.

Another good BTP session is ‚ÄúUnleash the power of your applications, data, and AI with SAP BTP.‚Äù

AI everywhere ‚Äì separating reality from hype

AI was top of mind for everyone as it played such a major role in the keynotes. The most common issues that people raised with me were:

  • Concerns about privacy of their data
  • How much of the capability is real and can the results be trusted?
  • Availability of AI functionality outside of SAP Cloud ERP and the associated costs

SAP Sapphire is all about the people

It was great to meet several colleagues in person for the first time and to connect with those that I see only a few times each year.

If we did not meet at Sapphire and you are interested in joining the conversation about SAP Fiori application development and how AI makes it better, faster, and cheaper, please join our monthly SAP Fiori development roundtable group or sign up for our bi-monthly newsletter.

For the UX Foundation team, Peter Spielvogel.

entry.title: Mastering Complex SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations
entry.content:
Welcome back to our new blog series,  our previous blog series  delved into the intricacies of dynamic sequential approval workflows.

In this two-part series, my colleague @Adwait_Fadnavis  and I will explore some very critical business workflow  requirements  in detail using SAP Build Process Automation. 

Throughout this blog series, we will delve into the following critical business requirements:

Part 1 - Current Blog :Mastering Complex SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations

Part 2 : Demonstration with Complete end to end testing 

We will demonstrate how to use various SAP Build Process Automation tools to solve real-time challenges effectively.

This blog post addresses this complex requirement with detailed step-by-step instructions. You'll learn how to ensure workflows advance smoothly, even with  approval condition utilizing various innovative latest features such as: Wait Step with API Triggering , Workflow Context update via API etc.

Business Context and Problem Statement

While working on multiple SAP Build Process Automation projects, we have faced situations where workflows only proceed if all departments or approvers approve them unanimously.

If any approver rejects the proposal, the entire workflow is rejected . This creates a need for a parallel approval process, adhering to an "all-or-nothing" requirement, which SAP's standard solutions do not support.

In a below sample procurement workflow, the request is created and submitted. Both the Department Manager and Finance Department must approve it simultaneously. If either rejects, the workflow is terminated.

If both approve, the request goes to the Executive for final approval. The Executive's decision determines whether the request is processed or terminated.

Dynamic Number of Parallel Approval
Technical Solutioning & Design

In this process, we will create two workflows using SAP Build Process Automation‚Äôs Low Code/No Code approach.

Let‚Äôs refer to these as Workflow A (main workflow) and Workflow B.

Workflow A( Main Workflow): This is the main workflow, triggered with all input parameters, responsible for the overall business process flow.

Workflow B(Secondary Workflow): This workflow handles the approval task. It receives the Approval ID, total number of levels, and current level. If the final approval is granted, it triggers a wait step API  in Workflow A to proceed to the next level. If more approvals are needed, it sends the Approval ID to the next level.

 
Technical Design Steps for Workflow A:
 
  1. Trigger Workflow: The workflow is initiated with input parameters.
  2. Decision Creation: A decision step is created to determine the number of approvals require. 

3. Script Task: This step determines the total number of approvals and the current approval level.

$.context.custom.doneapprovalcount = 0;
$.context.custom.currentcount = 0;
$.context.custom.subwfdefinationid = "Your Secondaray Workflow ID"; // replace with your secondary workflow id
$.context.custom.totalapprovalcount = $.context.decision_getAppprovers_1.Approvers.length;
$.context.custom.triggeredsubprocessids = [];
‚Äã
  • Condition Check: If the current level matches the total required approvals, A wait step will be created to wait for the completion. If not, Workflow B is triggered to initiate the approval task.

  • Trigger Workflow B: Workflow B sends the work item to the respective user for approval.
  • Wait Step API : This critical step waits for all parallel approvals to be completed. Once done, the dummy decision is triggered by Workflow B. This is very interesting and latest features
    1. Create a Wait Step with API as follows. After Deployment it will event will create the API End Point which will used to trigger from secondary workflow B .      
    2. Execution ID is the Parent Workflow ID.
    3. Upload the API specification and create the action for this
    4.  Also make sure to create the API key which will be used to trigger it from secondary workflow B.

Technical Design Steps for Workflow B  (Triggered via Workflow A)

  1. Trigger from Workflow A : Workflow B starts when Workflow A reaches a certain point to manage approval tasks separately and in parallel to the main workflow.

  2. Send Approval Task: The approval task is sent to the current level approver to obtain necessary approvals at each level before proceeding.
  3. On Approval: The system retrieves instance details and updates the approval count to keep track of completed approvals and update the workflow status.  
  4. sample code
$.context.custom.approvedcount = $.context.action_get_getV1WorkflowInstancesWorkflowInstanceIdContext_6.result.custom.doneapprovalcount + 1;
  • Check Count: The system checks if all required approvals are obtained:
    • If all approvals are done, the workflow proceeds to the next step.
    • If not all approvals are done This ensures the workflow only proceeds once all approvals are obtained
  •  Update Parent Workflow A Approval Action : increment the update count. created a custom action. If all the approvals not done, then update the approval count via custom action. (refer our previous blog how to create action for workflow API)   
  • Retrieve Task ID & Trigger Wait API trigger wait step ( API) in Workflow A to signal that the approval process is complete / Reject  and it can proceed.

entry.title: Quickly Generate and Deploy SAP Fiori Apps from ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse
entry.content:
Last year, SAP Fiori tools added a closer integration with ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse and enabled seamless navigation from ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse to SAP Fiori tools in both SAP Business Application Studio and Visual Studio Code. This enabled you to launch your configured external IDE environment and automatically start the SAP Fiori Application generator directly from the service binding editor in ADT. 

To increase your development productivity even more, this tool integration was now reused for the new Quick Fiori Application generator to create and deploy simple SAP Fiori applications. Like with SAP Fiori Tools in SAP Business Application Studio/Visual Studio Code, you as a developer are now able to generate an application based on SAP Fiori elements annotations and deploy the SAP Fiori UI effortlessly with only few clicks from the service binding editor in ADT. 

Want to know how?

  1. As a developer, create an OData UI Service based on the business object interface or CDS view suitable for UI consumption. OData UI services can be created in ABAP Development Tools for eclipse either manually by creating an OData UI service binding or by utilizing the Generate ABAP Repository Objects wizard. See Creating Service Binding and Generating ABAP Repository Objects.

  2. When creating the OData UI service in ABAP development tools for Eclipse, you must publish the corresponding service binding. For more information, see Using Service Binding Editor for OData V4 Service.

  3. In the service binding editor, select the entity set and choose Create Fiori App... 

     

  4. You now see two creation modes with which you can create SAP Fiori apps and deploy them to SAP BTP ABAP environment. Choose Create SAP Fiori app with Quick Fiori Application generator in ADT and choose Next.

     

  5. Enter the package name and configure the parameter values ensuring the repository name is unique and within 15 characters including namespace. Like in SAP Business Application Studio, the repository name corresponds to the name of the BSP application that gets generated post deployment. 

     

  6. Choose a transport request and choose Finish. The ABAP repository objects will be generated in the background, and you get a popup message once the objects are generated successfully. Choose Open to open or refresh the service binding.

  7. The BSP application and Fiori Launchpad App Descriptor item are generated in the chosen package along with two SICF objects. You now have a basic deployed Fiori app.

  8. In the service binding editor, you now see a clickable Fiori App URL. 


    Note, that the URL won't work for cloud systems immediately.     To consume services in an SAP Fiori app, you need to complete the following step.

  9. To allow business users to access the Fiori app, you must create an IAM app and link it to a business catalog. After that, your administrator can add your app to SAP Fiori Launchpad.
    Important: To make the app visible in the Fiori Launchpad in the end, the Fiori Launchpad App Descriptor Item that was generated after deployment needs to be added to the corresponding field in the IAM App. 


    This should automatically populate the OData service under the Services tab: 

That‚Äôs it! Easy, right? 

In the project explorer beneath your package, you now see the BSP application, the Launchpad App Descriptor item and the SICF objects along with the IAM app and the business catalog. 

To summarize, the new Quick Fiori Application generator ‚Äì available as of SAP BTP ABAP environment 2505 and ABAP development tools for Eclipse‚ÄØclient version‚ÄØ3.50 ‚Äì provides you the ability to quickly generate a productive Fiori app for simple use case (CRUD on tabular data) and configure Fiori Launchpad settings all in one without a tool switch. 

However, the Quick Fiori App generator only supports list report floorplan-based Fiori apps. Besides that, UI development capabilities are limited to backend Fiori elements annotations. For any UI changes, or if you want to delete, redeploy or undeploy the application, you must generate a Fiori project from the deployed application subsequently. As mentioned in the beginning of this blog post, the creation of a Fiori project is also supported via the Create Fiori App‚Ä¶ button in the Service Binding editor, from where you then can take over the project to SAP Business Application Studio/Visual Studio Code to perform further actions. Your Quick Fiori app will then be overwritten during deployment. 

We think, the Quick Fiori App generator is a powerful feature that enhances your productivity and enables you as a developer to deliver applications more rapidly and effectively.‚ÄØWhat do you think of this feature? Let us know in the comments!

entry.title: Support of SAP Build Work Zone, advanced and much more: SAP Mobile Start V2.2 & 2.3 - Release Update
entry.content:
In this blog, I will introduce the new features that we have released so far in 2025, with version V2.2 and our latest version V2.3.
When SAP Mobile Start got launched in August 2021, the app got automatically provisioned with SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition. In 2023, we added SAP Start and with the release V.2.2, SAP Mobile Start also connects to SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition.

When using SAP Mobile Start with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, you can now access your advanced edition content, like Workspaces or Feed Updates. As with the standard edition, your native and web apps are available within the Apps Screen of SAP Mobile Start, as well as in your Favorites Section on the Start Screen, based on your individual selection. This allows you direct and fast access to your business content while being mobile. 
What about the SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition tasks and notifications? If you have set up the Alert Notification Service and SAP Task Center Service, then you find them next to your business tasks and situations in the To-Do sections and in the Notification Center of SAP Mobile Start.

Screenshot: Notification Center with advanced edition notifications

We are looking forward to seeing many SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition and SAP SuccessFactors Work Zone customers to onboard to SAP Mobile Start, as it is automatically available if the SAP Mobile Start ‚Äútoggle‚Äù is enabled in the Site Manager.

Remark: SAP Mobile Start is not the successor app for the SAP Build Work Zone Advanced mobile app. SAP Mobile Start focuses on providing users easy access to their applications and business workflows. The app is deeply integrated into the device OS and provides native push notifications and widgets to ensure a best-in-class user experience. The SAP Build Work Zone Advanced mobile app focuses more on the collaboration aspects. Users can use both apps in parallel. Please also see our respective knowledge base article for further details. 

Besides seeing your latest open To-Dos in SAP Mobile Start, you can now also see your completed To-Dos. Just tap the ‚ÄúCompleted‚Äù filter button on the To-Do Screen and you will get your completed to-dos from the last six months right on the To-Dos Screen. You can also search across all open and completed to-dos via the search function.

Screenshot: Completed To-Dos

My favorite new feature is the site switch that is available with V2.3. This feature allows you to directly switch between SAP Build Work Zone sites. This is very helpful for IT teams but also for business users who work with multiple SAP Build Work Zone instances. Instead of always having to go through the complete onboarding process, the app offers you a list of recently used sites and you can just pick the one you need. Outdated sites can be deleted from your list with an easy swipe to the left. I am sure that you will love this feature.

Screenshots: Site Switch

Another nice enhancement comes for the news tiles. With the latest release of SAP Mobile Start, your news tile can also include news images. Furthermore, news feeds that require authentication are supported as well with the latest release. You just need to maintain the authenticated URL in the tile news property field ‚Äúmobilestart.feedUrl‚Äù in the site manager. Please have a look at our SAP Help documentation for details.

Screenshots: News with Image

You can now see the source system name on the app tiles with the latest release, what is very helpful if you have for instance connected multiple SAP S/4HANA systems to SAP Build Work Zone. The system name helps you to easily identify the system that is behind the tile. To use this feature, you can enable it in the Site Manager (‚ÄúDisplay: Show Source System Name on Tiles‚Äù).

Finally, the latest release provides some nice UX enhancements, like the enhanced navigation bar for Apple iPad and a new fresher design for monitoring details on Apple Watch. When you onboard to the app for the first time, a new in-app guide introduces the app features to you. In the Profile and Settings screen, you can now find detailed information about language settings for the app and for the displayed content; furthermore the app is now available in Hungarian.

Screenshot: New watch design 

I hope you will enjoy those new features in SAP Mobile Start.

entry.title: Unsafe-eval error in SAP Build Work Zone: Understanding and fixing a CSP blockage
entry.content:
While developing a SAP Fiori application in SAP Business Application Studio (BAS), I embedded an external component within a custom SAPUI5 component. The application worked perfectly in the local development environment, but once deployed into SAP Build Work Zone (BWZ), it no longer loaded as expected.

The browser console revealed an error related to the Content Security Policy (CSP), specifically due to the indirect use of eval(). This blog post summarizes my learnings about CSP and how I resolved the issue.

What is the Content Security Policy (CSP)?

CSP is a web security standard defined by the W3C and enforced by web browsers. It allows developers to control which resources (scripts, images, styles, etc.) a browser is allowed to load and execute, helping to prevent Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks and malicious script injections.

For example, the following directive means that only scripts from the same origin as the application are permitted.

Content-Security-Policy: script-src 'self'

Other common directives include:

  • style-src: Specifies allowed sources for stylesheets.
  • img-src: Limits where images can be loaded from.
  • connect-src: Defines allowed sources for fetching resources like APIs.
  • default-src: Specifies a fallback for all resource types if not otherwise defined.
  • frame-ancestors: Controls which sources can embed the page in an iframe.
  • ‚Ä¶ 

To learn more about CSP, refer to the official documentation on MDN: https://developer.mozilla.org/fr/docs/Web/HTTP/CSP

Problem context

The application was developed in SAP Business Application Studio and contained an external web component wrapped inside a custom SAPUI5 component.

Once deployed to SAP Build Work Zone, the interface no longer displayed at all. The browser console then showed the following error:

Unsafe-eval error (CSP Compliant)
Uncaught (in promise) EvalError:
Refused to evaluate a string as JavaScript because 'unsafe-eval' is not an allowed source of script
in the following Content Security Policy directive: "script-src * data: blob:".

Error Meaning

In CSP, dynamic functions like eval() or new Function() are blocked by default because they can introduce serious security risks. These functions allow JavaScript code to be generated and executed at runtime, which can be exploited to inject and run malicious scripts‚Äîcommonly associated with XSS attacks.

To protect the application's security, dynamic code execution is blocked by default in the Content Security Policy (CSP). Allowing it would require the inclusion of the unsafe-eval directive in the CSP, but this weakens security and should be avoided in production environments.

Root cause analysis

In the external component I used, I was generating an HTML element returned as a string (this is where I messed up). This HTML was then dynamically injected into the component‚Äôs DOM. However, the external component was interpreting this string using new Function(), violating CSP rules.

This behavior went unnoticed locally in Business Application Studio because CSP policies are often disabled or applied more leniently in development environments. However, in SAP Build Work Zone, a strict CSP is enforced, blocking dynamic code evaluation like this.

Implemented solution

By consulting the official documentation of the component, I found that I could provide a JavaScript function directly instead of passing a returned string containing HTML. This approach enables the component to use a safe rendering function, avoiding reliance on blocked mechanisms like eval() or new Function().

Here is an example of the new CSP-compliant code:

const generateDropdown = (aOptions) => {
  // Create the select element
  const oSelectElement = document.createElement('select');
  oSelectElement.classList.add('myCustomSelectClass');

  // Loop through the options array and create option elements
  aOptions.forEach(oOption => {
    const oOptionElement = document.createElement('option');
    oOptionElement.value = oOption.value;
    oOptionElement.textContent = oOption.label;

    // Append the option to the select
    oSelectElement.appendChild(oOptionElement); 
  });

  return oSelectElement;
};

// Example usage with an array of options
const options = [
  { value: '1', label: 'Option 1' },
  { value: '2', label: 'Option 2' },
  { value: '3', label: 'Option 3' }
];

// Generate the dropdown dynamically
generateDropdown(options);

Lessons learned

An application that works correctly in BAS may encounter critical errors in BWZ if it does not comply with the CSP. It is essential to prioritize the use of real JavaScript functions over injecting HTML or JavaScript code as strings. Often, the documentation for external components provides alternative solutions that are CSP-compliant, and these should be carefully considered.

Conclusion

The Content Security Policy is an essential tool for securing web applications against XSS attacks and the execution of uncontrolled code. In environments like SAP Build Work Zone, CSP is strictly enforced, which can lead to unexpected errors.

By adapting our implementation to comply with CSP rules, we not only ensure the compatibility of our applications but also enhance their security. I hope this feedback will be useful to you.

entry.title: $expand in UI5 SmartTable AnalyticalTable combo
entry.content:
Introduction

Hi and welcome to my next SAP Community blog post.

Even though, as of the time of writing this, the official UI5 SmartTable documentation does not say it, it is NOT possible to use $expand parameter with an AnalyticalTable used in SmartTable component. 

Actually, an example found in the SmartTable documentation might mislead into thinking, that it IS possible to do so. However, it is not... (https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/sdk/#/api/sap.ui.comp.smarttable.SmartTable%23faq)

In this blog, I will show you how to overcome this with a simple implementation of a custom JavaScript logic.

Root Cause

The root cause of the issue can be found in method _getQueryODataRequestOptions of class AnalyticalBinding. This is the binding used by the AnalyticalTable.

As you can see in the image pasted above, the $expand parameter is not taken into account when the query parameters are being parsed. 

Solution

A custom logic can be created to override this behavior. The logic should first copy the reference to the original logic (so that it can still be used) and add any additional logic we need.

For example:

// Override the original code of _getQueryODataRequestOptions method
// to allow $expand OData URL parameter for Analytical Table
_addExpandToAnalyticalBinding: function () {
  var that = this;
  this.fnGetQueryODataRequestOptionsOriginalLogic = sap.ui.model.analytics.AnalyticalBinding.prototype._getQueryODataRequestOptions;
  this.fnGetQueryODataRequestOptionsCustomLogic = function (oAnalyticalQueryRequest, bAddAdditionalSelects, mParameters) {
    var aResults = that.fnGetQueryODataRequestOptionsOriginalLogic.apply(this, arguments);

    // Add the needed $expand parameter values
    aResults.push("$expand=to_Items,to_Vendor");

    return aResults;
  };
}

 The _addExpandToAnalyticalBinding method can be called in the onInit handler of the view controller.

onInit: function () {
  this._addExpandToAnalyticalBinding();
}

And in the onBeforeRebindSmartTable event handler (for the "beforeRebindTable" event of a SmartTable control) the old logic should be overwritten with the new one.

onBeforeRebindSmartTable: function (oEvent) {
  // Override the original code of _getQueryODataRequestOptions method
  // to allow $expand OData URL parameter for Analytical Table
  sap.ui.model.analytics.AnalyticalBinding.prototype._getQueryODataRequestOptions = this.fnGetQueryODataRequestOptionsCustomLogic;
}

This way the standard logic will be appended with the needed $expand values.

Edit: I've noticed that there is an attributed in the AnalyticalBinding called sCustomParams. It could be used to add the $expand parameter to the OData call. Unfortunately, the AnalyticalBinding is not available when the AnalyticalTable is refreshed for the first time. The solution could be:

onBeforeRebindSmartTable: function (oEvent) {
  var oBinding = oEvent.getSource().getTable().getBinding();
  if (oBinding) {
    oBinding.sCustomParams = "$expand=to_Items,to_Vendor";
  }
  
  // Override the original code of _getQueryODataRequestOptions method
  // to allow $expand OData URL parameter for Analytical Table
  sap.ui.model.analytics.AnalyticalBinding.prototype._getQueryODataRequestOptions = this.fnGetQueryODataRequestOptionsCustomLogic;
}

The $expand string could also be moved to a separate method, common to both places

entry.title: How to Embed a PowerBI Report within a Custom Fiori UI5 app
entry.content:
Hi Folks, 

In this post I'll go over a simple yet powerful requirement: embedding a PowerBI report in a custom SAP UI5 Fiori application. This can be a great way to enrich your Fiori applications with rich, interactive analytics. Utilize this to create a seamless, unified user experience which puts data-driven insights right where decisions are made.

Prerequisites

  1. A Power BI report that you are ready to share.
  2. Access to the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and the Business Application Studio (BAS).

 

Step 1: Get the Public Embed Code from Power BI

  1. Generate a link for our Power BI report. This is the simplest method for embedding.
  2. Follow the steps from the Microsoft knowledge base on how to embed Power BI reports into portals (also see screenshot)

 

Step 2: Create a new Fiori app in Business Application Studio

  1. Open Business Application Studio and start a new project from template
  2. Select ‚ÄúSap Fiori Generator‚Äù
  3. Select ‚ÄúBasic‚Äù
  4. Select ‚ÄúNone‚Äù for Data Source. We don't need to connect to an OData service for this example.
  5. Input a View Name followed by Project Attributes and click ‚ÄúFinish‚Äù

 

Step 3: Add the Code for embedding to your XML view

  1. Navigate to your project‚Äôs webapp > view folder and open the xml view you created.  
  2. Replace the existing code and insert the following code snippet in your home page view xml.
  3. Modify the controllerName, and from the content modify the frame title, width, height, src, and frameborder as necessary.
<mvc:View
    controllerName="com.mycompany.powerbiapp.controller.Home"
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
    xmlns="sap.m"
    xmlns:core="sap.ui.core">
    <Page id="page" title="INPUT_A_TITLE_HERE">
        <content>
            <core:HTML
                id="powerBIFrame"
                content='<iframe title="INPUT_A_TITLE_HERE " width="100%"
                height="100%" src=" INSERT_YOUR_POWER_BI_EMBED_URL_HERE "
                frameborder="0" allowFullScreen="true"></iframe>'>
            </core:HTML>
        </content>
    </Page>
</mvc:View>
  • Notice the < and >
  • ^ This is crucial! In XML views, you must escape the < and > characters with their HTML entity equivalents (< and >) to ensure the XML is valid.

(Example from my project)

 

Step 4: Preview your application

  1. Once your project is modified, save your project and preview the application by right clicking on the webapp folder and select ‚Äúpreview application.‚Äù
  2.  Choose one of the available preview scripts that shows up in the command palette (e.g., start-local).

Your Fiori application will launch in a new browser tab and you should see your PowerBI report embedded within your application

(Example from my project)

 

I hope you found this guide useful. Feel free to leave your questions and feedback in the comments below.

entry.title: I Skipped Fiori (And I'd Do It Again)
entry.content:
Or: How TRIZ Taught Me The Best UI Is No UI

 Hey SAP folks! üëã

 

Deep breath.

I have a confession: I skipped Fiori. Just like I skipped SAP Smart Forms (jumping straight from SAPscript to Adobe Forms) and WebDynpro (leaping from SAPGUI to Fiori). Before you assume I'm just another anti-Fiori rebel, hear me out.

I loved Fiori when it launched in 2013. Finally, SAP that didn't look like Windows 95! Responsive design! Tiles! But it's 2025, and we're still... clicking... through... tiles... to... do... everything.

After working with Fiori since 2015, I had an epiphany that would make any TRIZ (innovation theory) person weep with joy:

"The ideal system is one that doesn't exist but its function is performed."

The "This Can't Be The Future" Moment

Picture this: 9‚ÄØAM Monday. CFO pings you: "Need the latest P&L for company‚ÄØ1000 ‚Äî compare this quarter to last, right now."

  • Find "Financial Statement Analysis" app
  • Click tile (wait for app to load)
  • Select company code from dropdown
  • Choose fiscal period and year
  • Apply profit center filters
  • Navigate through multiple screens
  • Export to Excel for actual analysis

Time: ~4 minutes ¬∑ 23 clicks ¬∑ 8 screens ¬∑ Frustration: Daily

 

The 2025 Way:

entry.title: Explore SAPUI5/OpenUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free
entry.content:
Executive summary

SAPUI5 / OpenUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free is available to test your code for future-proof best practices and to provide early feedback to the UI5 team.

Why?

The UI5 team introduces the SAPUI5 / OpenUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free version to mark a significant milestone in our journey towards modernizing UI5 applications. It introduces a legacy-free UI5 framework with deprecated code removed, resulting in a leaner and more efficient codebase. Going forward, this step is crucial for improving performance, reducing maintenance efforts, and enabling faster innovation for both, the UI5 framework itself as well as applications built with SAPUI5 / OpenUI5.

The new SAPUI5 / OpenUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free version allows to evolve in these areas:

  • Best practices for app development: A legacy-free UI5 framework paves the way for application developers to follow UI5 best practices. With streamlined, clear APIs, application developers learn and develop with SAPUI5 / OpenUI5 more easily. (Note that applying the UI5 best practices is not a new recommendation or a one-time effort for a specific version. SAP recommends following these best practices continuously to leverage innovations more easily.)
  • Startup performance: With the modular core, new bootstrap and additional opportunities to improve performance we expect to see a better experience when launching and using apps.
  • Smooth UI performance: The legacy-free UI5 framework mandates efficient code to achieve an improved UI performance more easily. This happens e.g. by using fine granular tasks and asynchronous JavaScript only.
  • Browser / Web standards: A legacy-free UI5 framework makes it easier to stay up to date with the browser evolution and to follow latest Web standards. Content Security Policy (CSP) compliance ensures improved application security.
  • Micro frontends: The removal of global variables simplifies the orchestration of micro frontends.
  • Speed of innovation: It becomes easier for application developers to make progress and innovate with new features. Also, the UI5 framework itself can deliver requested capabilities more rapidly. At the same time, less resources are needed for maintenance, shifting the focus towards innovative, yet stable capabilities and a future-proof applications with upcoming SAPUI5 / OpenUI5 versions.

In this context we conducted a Customer Engagement Initiative project in 2024 and received very positive feedback from a small group of customers/partners. We now want to give anyone the opportunity to

  • test how compliant your existing code is to UI5 best practices,
  • ensure that your new code is state-of-the-art and future-proof,
  • provide your concrete, technical feedback directly to the UI5 team.

What?

The UI5 team provides cloud access to the SAPUI5 / OpenUI5 1.136 legacy-free version with deprecated code removed. This version is generally available under the terms of the SAP Developer License Agreement, not to be used in productive scenarios. Also see SAP Note 3621332.

  1. Explore SAPUI5 / OpenUI5 1.136 legacy-free: We encourage you to validate your app developments against this new version, while you continue using a usual standard 1.x version for your productive environments.
  2. Make an impact: Test your app and report issues with the 1.136 legacy-free version to the UI5 team.

The UI5 team strongly recommends developing apps without using legacy code
to ensure your app is modern and future-proof.

 

UI5 Demo Kit with UI5 Best Practices

How?

Follow the steps detailed out in Using the 1.x-legacy-free Versions:

  1. Check your code against the UI5 Best Practices, specifically the Best Practices for SAPUI5 1.136-legacy-free. The UI5 linter helps analyzing & autofixing your code.
  2. Bootstrap your app with UI5 1.136.x-legacy-free from the UI5 cloud CDN:
      • https://ui5.sap.com/1.136.3-legacy-free   https://sdk.openui5.org/1.136.3-legacy-free
      • https://ui5.sap.com/1.136-legacy-free      https://sdk.openui5.org/1.136-legacy-free      (evergreen version)
      • https://ui5.sap.com/1-legacy-free              https://sdk.openui5.org/1-legacy-free              (default version)

  3. Test run your app in the Preview (sandbox) of SAP Build Code / SAP Business Application Studio.
  4. Report issues to the UI5 team:
    • SAPUI5: Create an incident on the respective component within CA-UI5*, using ‚Äú[LF]‚Äù as prefix of the subject. (Formally, this delivery has no SAP standard support / service level agreement, and your incidents might be set to priority Low. Still, the UI5 team will learn from your feedback and plan/implement required features.)
    • OpenUI5: Create an issue in OpenUI5 GitHub, using ‚Äú[LF]‚Äù as prefix of the title. 

Going forward

The planned* release strategy follows quarterly new versions of legacy-free SAPUI5 / OpenUI5:

  • 1.136.x-legacy-free
  • 1.139.x-legacy-free
  • ‚Ä¶

We plan to delete SAPUI5 / OpenUI5 legacy-free versions 4 weeks after a newer version (release or patch) is available or when SAP stops the option to explore SAPUI5/OpenUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free altogether.

Note: This initiative is part of SAPUI5's ongoing effort to innovate the SAPUI5 / OpenUI5 framework towards a modern and future-proof code base. At the current point in time, we do not have a timeline for next steps in this context. As soon as available, we'll publish in official UI5 channels such as the SAPUI5 Road Map, UI5 mailing list and UI5 announcements, LinkedIn, and Bluesky. The SAPUI5 team appreciates your patience and looks forward to your feedback as we continue to evolve and improve SAPUI5 / OpenUI5 and applications built with it.

entry.title: BO Interface APIs : An alternative to BAPIs and traditional FMs
entry.content:
Objective:

We would be needing to create or update master/transaction data in S4 system. In our example, we need to update line items of Purchase Order using code. 

Approach: 

Initially, the plan was to use the BAPI 'BAPI_PO_CHANGE'  which is a proven method to update Purchase Order. We will be currently using an alternative approach of using BO interfaces for updating the line items of PO.

What are BO Interfaces?

SAP has provided many Fiori apps which are built by using Business Object underneath. These Business Objects contain the paradigm to update its relevant data. They have their own entities using which we can create or change the data.

Why do we need to user BO Interfaces?

Even though there are proven BAPIs or FMs available to do the job, still SAP has provided BO interfaces. They have a few advantages as shown below:

1. SAP is adding new functionalities to its product periodically. A few of the modules (e.g. Treasury) have Fiori apps which do not have an SAP GUI transaction as alternative (When building a custom solution). As these have been implemented completely in Fiori, we may or may not have FMs to interact with database. In such cases, BO interfaces will be a boon for us to interact with the DB rather than we debugging and copying standard code to replicate the same functionality. 

2. Some of the FMs will require us to call a COMMIT statement to save the data to DB. When we are building a Fiori app using RAP, we will not be able to call COMMIT work in our behavior class. (We use RFC calls to update data and call COMMIT which a workaround). These statements do not require a COMMIT when called from behavior class.

How do we find BO Interfaces?

The following steps can be used to see if there is any standard BO interface available for our need.

1. As a first step, we need to visit https://api.sap.com/ and go 'Categories' tab in which you will be able to see the tile for Business Object Interface:

2. Once you get into the tile, you'll be able to see a list of released BO interfaces provided by SAP. As of now, there are 348 BO Interfaces provided by standard.

3. For our scenario, we need to see if there is a BO interface to create or change Purchase Order. Type 'Purchase Order' in the search and hit enter upon which you'll be able to see all the results.

4. The relevant BO Interface is visible as a first tile for us. If you a closer look at the tile, it will tell us the capabilities of the BO interface. Ours' is capable of CRUD operation of Purchase Orders.

5. Once you click the tile, you will be taken to the details screen of the selected BO interface. The information such as underlying CDS view entities, Released state, Operations, and the associated entities will be visible.

6. We are clicking on create of Purchase Order projection. We should be able to see the authorization objects and a sample request which says how the data needs to be passed to the BO Interface.

What are the prerequisites for using BO Interfaces?

 We can classify it into two:

1. System requirement

We would be needing an S4 system to use these BO Interfaces.

2. Developer requirement

We need to familiar with EML (Entity Manipulation Language) which is needed for performing the actions using the BO Interfaces. 

How to use BO Interfaces in our code?

I have created a sample SE38 report program to update Purchase Order. (This report program contains only the core logic required for this article)

1. We are fetching the data from the CDS entity I_PURCHASEORDERITEMTP_2. I am using the CDS view as I am familiar with it. You can do the same by doing a simple SELECT to EKPO table.

2. We are using an EML statement to update a field in PO Line item.  In the below code, we need to pass the keys and the value to be updated. The field relevant for update is set using if_abap_behv=>mk-on. You can also additionally add parameters of FAILED to see if the data got updated successfully. (You'll be familiar with it once you go through EML)

COMMIT ENTITIES is required as EML is called outside behavior class.

3. We are again doing a fetch to see if the data got updated successfully.

4. The entire set of code looks like below.

5. When executed via debugger, the variables in the right shows the old value and the updated value.

Note:

Similar set of code can be used to update the custom field. There are 2 pre-requisite for updating the custom field using the above approach

1. The field should be added via Custom Fields app. The fields that are directly added to DB table via APPEND structures will not be visible as the field is not added to the underlying CDS entities.

2. Fields added via Custom fields app needs the setting to be enabled. You need to enable usage for the field in the CDS entity. This can be done when creating the custom field.

entry.title: SAP Fiori Deployment in 2025: Embedded vs. Work Zone Standard vs. Advanced Edition
entry.content:
As SAP advances its strategy toward a unified and intelligent user experience, organizations are increasingly required to re-evaluate their SAP Fiori deployment models. Traditional architectures, such as the Central Hub, are being phased out in favor of more modern, cloud-based solutions like SAP Build Work Zone‚Äîavailable in both Standard and Advanced editions.

This shift presents a strategic decision point for IT leaders: selecting the most appropriate deployment model that aligns with their existing system landscape, integration needs, and long-term digital goals. Understanding the strengths and trade-offs of Embedded Fiori, Work Zone Standard, and Work Zone Advanced is essential for designing a scalable and user-centric enterprise environment.

This guide compares all three modern deployment approaches so you can make an informed, future-proof decision.

Option 1: Embedded Deployment (Frontend + Backend in S/4HANA)

What it is: Fiori frontend server and Launchpad are embedded directly into the SAP S/4HANA system.

Best for:

  • Greenfield S/4HANA implementations
  • Simpler landscapes with no need to federate apps from multiple sources

Pros:

  • Simplified architecture
  • Lower total cost of ownership
  • Direct and efficient performance
  • No additional BTP subscription needed

Cons:

  • Not ideal for hybrid system landscapes (e.g., ECC + S/4)
  • Downtime impacts entire stack
  • Limited flexibility for UI extensions or content aggregation

Option 2: SAP Build Work Zone, Standard Edition
(Successor to Central Hub deployment)

What it is: A cloud-based launchpad-as-a-service running on SAP BTP. Provides centralized access to apps and content from multiple SAP systems.

Best for:

  • Customers with hybrid environments (e.g., ECC, S/4HANA, CRM)
  • Users needing a unified Launchpad across systems

Pros:

  • Aggregates apps from multiple systems
  • Personalizable Launchpad (cards, themes, roles)
  • Prebuilt integration with SAP apps like Ariba, SuccessFactors, and Concur
  • Low-code extensibility with SAP Build tools
  • Lower entry point than Advanced edition

Cons:

  • Limited support for advanced workflows or custom page layouts
  • Less extensibility for 3rd-party or custom content
  • No native document management or microsite capabilities

Option 3: SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition
(For full digital experience and enterprise portal replacement)

What it is: An enterprise-grade digital workplace platform built on SAP BTP + SAP Launchpad + SAP Work Zone + SAP Build Pages + SAP Knowledge Base. It replaces traditional SAP Enterprise Portal and delivers full-scale intranet functionality.

Best for:

  • Customers replacing SAP Enterprise Portal
  • Organizations needing to integrate SAP and non-SAP apps
  • Use cases requiring business content, collaboration, workflows, and knowledge-sharing

Pros:

  • Advanced page builder for intranet-like UX
  • Deep integration with Microsoft 365, Teams, SharePoint, and 3rd-party systems
  • Role-based content delivery with custom navigation layouts
  • Embedded SAP Task Center, Process Automation, Knowledge Base
  • Ideal for large, multi-LOB organizations

Cons:

  • Higher cost and complexity than Standard edition
  • Requires thoughtful implementation planning
  • Best suited for organizations with mature digital transformation goals

Comparison table:

 

DeploymentOn S/4HANA systemSAP BTPSAP BTP
System Scope1 system (S/4HANA)Multiple SAP systemsSAP + 3rd-party apps
UX FlexibilityBasic LaunchpadLaunchpad + basic cardsFull page editor, custom layouts
CollaborationNoneNonewikis, forums, Teams
Document ManagementNoneNoneAvailable
Task Center / WorkflowBasic InboxFederated InboxEmbedded SAP Task Center
M365 IntegrationNoneNoneAvailable
Use Case FitSimplicity & speedCentral accessFull digital workplace
Ideal ForS/4HANA-only landscapesHybrid SAP appsPortal replacement + collaboration
CostNo additional BTP costMediumHigher

Conclusion

Establishing a unified point of entry for enterprise users is essential to an effective SAP Fiori deployment strategy. Whether an organization operates within a single SAP S/4HANA system or manages a complex, multi-system landscape, selecting the appropriate deployment model ensures enhanced usability, simplified maintenance, and long-term adaptability.

Embedded Fiori is best suited for organizations running a clean, standalone SAP S/4HANA environment. It provides a streamlined, fully self-contained user experience without requiring integration with other SAP or non-SAP systems‚Äîmaking it an efficient and cost-effective option for focused landscapes.

SAP Build Work Zone ‚Äì Standard Edition is recommended for scenarios involving multiple SAP backend systems, such as ECC, CRM, or BW. It serves as a centralized launchpad, delivering a consistent user experience across the enterprise.

SAP Build Work Zone ‚Äì Advanced Edition is ideal for companies seeking to replace SAP Enterprise Portal or establish a robust digital workplace. With capabilities for cross-application integration, collaboration, document management, and connectivity to third-party platforms like Microsoft 365, it supports a modern and extensible enterprise UX.

SAP Build Work Zone‚Äîavailable in both Standard and Advanced Editions‚Äîrepresents the evolution of SAP‚Äôs UX strategy, replacing legacy frontend models with a cloud-native, scalable platform aligned with digital transformation goals.

Ultimately, the deployment choice should reflect the organization's current IT architecture, user requirements, and future roadmap. Aligning SAP Fiori strategy with these considerations enables a future-ready user experience that empowers employees and streamlines system management.

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP ‚Äì Q2 2025
entry.content:
Q2 was another big quarter for SAP Business Technology Platform. From application development to integration and analytics, we are excited to share how SAP BTP continues to simplify, streamline, and speed things up! Let's dive into some of the top innovations!

App Dev & Automation Highlights 

Simplified SAPUI5 extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard 

If your business relies on cloud ERP as its IT backbone, you know it may need extensions to meet unique requirements. When built-in extensibility isn‚Äôt enough,‚ÄØSAP Build on SAP BTP offers powerful options for custom coding and SAP Fiori UI extensions.  

Now, with the‚ÄØSAP Build Extensibility Wizard, you can create UI extensions directly from your cloud ERP application. By launching the Extensibility Wizard directly from your SAP Fiori application, you are given different options for the type of extension you want to create.

The 'User Interface Extension' lets you either adapt the existing Fiori app or create a new custom application. By setting up your destinations and details in the Wizard, you can either remove sections, add new fields, and create a completely new variant of the application with SAP Build Code and Business Application Studio. Developers and key users can already use it to create custom processes and now, custom user interfaces. 

Watch the video‚ÄØdemo (starting at 0:08) ‚ÄØfor more insights!   

Learn more:  Simplify SAPUI5 Code Extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

Application to Enable Business Users to Manage Decisions

To empower business users to view or maintain decisions within SAP Build Process Automation, we launched a dedicated, purpose-built application that can be accessed directly from SAP Build Work Zone ‚Äì without the need of IT. 

Business users can access a dedicated application in SAP Build Work Zone to manage decisions within a single project. Users can open the decision table, modify values directly, or import data from Excel and then save their changes, seeing only what matters and making the experience clean and focused. The release of a changed version is only one click away. Any errors are shown in the design console, letting users view the different versions of the project. 

See for yourself in the demo (starting at 2:05) ‚ÄØfor more insights!

Learn more 

  • Configure the Stuido Home Application 
  • Using the Studio Home Application

Partner Solutions as an Installable Product on SAP BTP ABAP Environment 

Good news for SAP partners developing apps with SAP BTP ABAP Environment: you can now offer your solution not only as a multitenant Software as a Service solution, but also as an installable product! 

Customers can now install the solution directly in their system as a product. As a part of SAP BTP ABAP Environment, the Landscape Portal supports both delivery options: multitenant SaaS and installable product. 

You can do this in three easy steps:

  1. Build your product with the Register Product app. 
  2. Choose your delivery model: 
    • For multitenant SaaS, configure it in the Maintain Solution app  
    • For installable product, use the Publish Product app. 
  3. Publish your solution to the SAP Store with a PartnerEdge Build contract and an SAP Store enhancement. 

Now customers using SAP BTP ABAP Environment can find your product in the SAP Store and install it into their own system using the Deploy Product option. 

For detailed guidance, watch the demo (starting at 3:42). 

Learn more: Building partner products on SAP BTP ABAP Environment

Integration Highlight

Describe Externalized Parameters of an Integration Flow 

In SAP Integration Suite externalization enables integration developers to define parameters as variables for certain configurations of adapters or flow steps of an integration flow. The values of these parameters can be changed without editing the integration flow, for example, when moving integrations from development or test environment to production. To simplify the understanding of this difficult and technical process, content developers can now provide descriptions directly in the integration flow editor. These can be the potential values, examples or additional details explaining the impact of specific values which will then be visible for guiding through each of the fields in the Configure view. This brings huge potential to improve the maintainability and reusability of your integration scenarios.  

Take a look at the demo (starting at 5:21) and see for yourself! 

Learn more: Externalized Parameters View

Data & Analytics Highlight

Analytical insights in Joule 

Joule, SAP's copilot, now enables you to get quick analytical answers without having to build reports. This provides you with valuable insights, saving time and giving you the information you need. 

Joule scans available data sources and suggests a few options, making comparisons to previous months easier. Joule updates the view right away, making it easy to see how things are trending. For example, you can ask for the top ten sales agents, check the monthly commission trend from January to March, giving you contextual and relevant answers 

See this in action in the demo (starting 7:15).

Learn more: Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly

Cross Platform Highlight

Provision App-Specific Groups in Identity Directory 

SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant enables immediate provisioning of authorizations to target systems‚ÄØin SAP Analytics Cloud target system. You can‚ÄØ centrally manage user-group assignments linked to application-specific policies, triggering provisioning jobs that synchronize access rights efficiently and securely. This ensures users gain prompt access to their designated roles in the target system.

Watch the demo (starting at 8:37) for a closer look. 

Learn more: SAP Cloud Identity Services

entry.title: Adaptation Project in SAP BAS: Add Navigation to Manage Credit Limit Requests (F5602)
entry.content:
Objective: This blog post provides insights about the implementation required to enhance the SAP standard Fiori application ‚ÄúManage Credit Limit Requests (F5602)‚Äù.  and how to implement the Adaptation Project in SAP Business Application Studio environment. 


In this blog post, I‚Äôll demonstrate the implementation required to enhance the SAP standard Fiori application ‚ÄúManage Credit Limit Requests (F5602)‚Äù.

The improvement includes:

  • Navigation Push button that redirects to the Manage Customer Line Items (FBL5N) using intent-based navigation and passes the Business Partner (BP) as a parameter.

The adaptation will be done using SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) by leveraging the adaptation project framework, ensuring non-intrusive changes.

So, let‚Äôs get started, 

Implementation in SAP BAS:

  • Click on File and select New Project from Template.

  • In the Project from Template, select SAPUI5 Adaptation Project and click on Start.

  • Select Environment (ABAP) and click on Next.

  • Select the Backend System and provide credentials, then select Application (F5602) and click on Next.

  • Give the Project name, Description, and click on Finish.

  • Below is the basic structure of the Adaptation Application when we create.

  • Left-click on the application, select Adaptation Project, and select Open Adaptation Editor.

  • Click on Navigation, click on the go button and expand the combo box, and click on Table line item so that you navigate to Credit Case Object Page.

  • Select UI Adaptation for doing adaptation.

  • Left click on the Toolbar and select Add: Fragment.

  • Select Target aggregation as action to add button and give the Fragment Name (PushBtn.fragment.xml) and click on Create.

  • Left-click on the Toolbar and select Extend with Controller.

  • Give the Controller Name (PushBtn.js) and click on Create

  • Click on the Save button at the top.

  • Below is the structure of the Adaptation Application when we create an add button fragment and Extend controller.

  • Fragment Logic to add Press event to the button.

XML CODE SNIPPET:
<core:FragmentDefinition xmlns:core="sap.ui.core" xmlns="sap.m">
<!--   add your xml here  -->
<Button text="{i18n>PushButton}" id="btn-cf48eefd" press=".extension.customer.zmclr.PushButton.onPressPush"/>
</core:FragmentDefinition>
  • Controller Logic for Press event of button (onPressPush)
    • Navigation Type: Intent-based navigation using a Semantic Object and Action
      • Example:   
        • Semantic Object: Customer
        • Action: manageLineItems
        • Parameters: Customer=<BusinessPartner>

Note: Getting Navigation Information from the Below Link, i.e., SAP Fiori app Library

IMPLEMENTATION INFORMATION ‚Äì Configuration - Target Mapping: https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('FBL5N')/S30PCE  

 

Controller Code:
    onPressPush: function (oEvent) {
                var that = this;
                var Items = that.getView().byId("fscm.cr.clcr::sap.suite.ui.generic.template.ObjectPage.view.Details::CreditLimitRequest--MainDataFacet::BusinessPartner::Field");
                var oObject = Items.getBindingContext().getObject();
                var BusinessPartner = oObject.BusinessPartner;// read BusinessPartner
                var oCrossAppNavigator = sap.ushell.Container.getService("CrossApplicationNavigation"); // get a handle on the global XAppNav service
                var hash = (oCrossAppNavigator && oCrossAppNavigator.hrefForExternal({
                    target: {
                        semanticObject: "Customer",
                        action: "manageLineItems"
                    },
                    params: {
                        "Customer": BusinessPartner
                    }
                })) || ""; // generate the Hash to display a Supplier
                oCrossAppNavigator.toExternal({
                    target: {
                        shellHash: hash
                    }
                }); // navigate to Supplier application
            }
  • The screen below is after adding the button fragment and Extend controller, adding button Press event.

Deployment from SAP BAS to ABAP:

  • Left click on the application, select Adaptation Project, and select Open Deployment Wizard.

  • Give credentials to log in to the System and click on Next.

  • Select the System and click on Next.

  • Enter the Package and click on Next.

  • Enter Transport Request Number and click on Finish. The application will be deployed successfully.

After Deployment (Output):

  • After opening "Manage Credit Limit Requests" tile and we can see the screen below and click on the "Go" button in the Smart Filter Bar.

  • Expand the combo box and select any option. Results (list of credit limit requests) are displayed in the Smart Table.

  • Click on any row in the result table. Navigation occurs to the Object Page (Detail View) for the selected credit request.

  • On click on the Push button, Intent-based navigation by passing the Business Partner Number as a Parameter to Manage Customer Line Items (FBL5N)

  • Manage Customer Line Items (FBL5N) Navigation view is below

Conclusion: Hope this blog post will give a better understanding of implementing and deploying the Adaptation Project in SAP Business Application Studio environment. 


Feel free to share your feedback or thoughts in the comments. Happy Learning.

Thanks for Reading,
Swathi Rani.
